Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the mortality rate of the United States from COVID-19, stating that it is one of the lowest in the world, which is not supported by data.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the United States does not have one of the lowest mortality rates from COVID-19, as there are at least 15 advanced, industrialized nations with lower rates.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the statement that the United States has one of the lowest mortality rates.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the mortality rate of the United States is among the lowest in the world without providing any evidence or justification for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides alternative explanations by stating that there are other countries, including Brazil, Mexico, South Africa, Russia, Turkey, Argentina, and India, that have lower mortality rates than the United States.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it incorrectly refers to the case-fatality rate as the "mortality rate" and does not accurately represent the current situation of the United States' mortality rate from COVID-19.
Understate: The claim understates the mortality rate of the United States by stating that it is one of the lowest in the world, when in fact there are many countries with lower rates.
